messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:41): where does http://bitbucket.org/ms2ger/dom-range/ allow me to actually see the spec?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:47): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: http://bitbucket.org/ms2ger/dom-range/raw/555ad6ae74fa/source.html ?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:47): that seems to have content-disposition headers
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:48): but it'll do, thanks
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:49): anyone write arabic fluently here?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:49): or hebrew?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:01): Just when I thought HyBi couldn't get any worse, people started top posting
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:05): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, can you modify that multipart algo so it's easier to invoke from outside of <form>? i.e. from FormData
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:05): yeah that seems reasonable. file a bug describing what interface you want and i'll make sure to make it available.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:06): cool

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:13): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: BTW on the subject of HyBi, it seems that NPN has difficult deployment issues e.g. there was some suggestion that it would make writing a server in java hard until some hypothetical future java release
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:14): So it seems to me that the compromise solution is the best option on the table at the moment
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:14): oh yes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:14): or we could just update java
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:14): Unicode 6 adds support for emoji
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:14): unicode 6 has a fantastic set of new characters
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:14): i can't wait for fonts!
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:15): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: You plan to ship Java 1.7 as part of WebSockets? That is... ambitious
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:15): at the current rate, it's unclear to me which will ship first
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:15): i know people are working on java 1.7 and making progress
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:15): it's unclear if the same can be said of websockets
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:15): phases of the moon have characters too
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:16): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: (anyway you don't need a new java, just a new TLS library)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:18): aah NY Times cannot spell HTML5
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:20): I see that article was already discussed...
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:20): I worry more about the less obvious means of tracking not discussed by the much cited EverCookie (or whatever it was called)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:20): you mean they can't spell HTTP
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:20): the ones Bj??rn mentioned
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:21): like DNS caching, fingerprinting, HTTP indeed, etc.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:22): and we could probably reduce risk significantly, but then everything will be dogslow and legit stuff will stop working
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:24): we really should reduce fingerprinting, if only as an excuse to remove the crap from our HTTP requests like Accept-Encoding and whatnot
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:24): and to simplify the UA strings
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:24): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: you pinged me
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:24): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: well, yt'ed.

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:25): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: The speed-to-spec-completion argument works heavily against NPN. NPN was just as controversial for the TLS people as WebSockets has been for HTTP people
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:25): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: ah yeah. i think i ended up asking the question on a bug.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:26): I'm wondering if there's anything other than CSS and Web Apps that I should request observer status for
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:26): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: controversy in a wg is imho irrelevant, what matters is whether UAs will implement.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:26): for TPAC week, that is
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:28): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, yeah, we're killing Accept-Encoding and some useless User-Agent bits for starters
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:28): in a way, I'm tempted to observe the TAG meeting
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:28): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: The two may be somewhat related when you want changes on both clients and server sides
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:29): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, masochist? ;p
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:29): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: in my experience, servers will implement whatever it takes to interop with the clients.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:29): Since there is likely to be non-trivial overlap between the people who are unhappy and the implementors of major components
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:29): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: (and precisely nothing more)

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:30): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: (even if doing more is the right thing for future extensibility... which is why i'd specced the error handling differently in the old websockets drafts for client and server)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:34): was http://www.0xdeadbeef.com/weblog/2010/10/websockets-shipping-before-its-ready/ mentioned here already?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:34): I get called out for not prefixing in Opera's experimental release while Firefox 4 betas ship unprefixed too
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:36): until 7 days ago it wasn't even clear whether Mozilla was considering shipping a prefixed version judging from b.m.o
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (11:36): the decision is changing twice a week
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:36): way to wake up
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:38): he probably just misunderstood what you were shipping
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:40): well unless something changes our final will ship unprefixed too
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:41): we're not a market leader, we cannot really afford being incompatible
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:41): if Chrome et al were shipping with a prefixed version of some kind, so would we
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:44): are you actually shipping -76 or are you shipping the fixed version of -00 that's on the whatwg.org site and marked as obsolete?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:46): oh, -00 I guess
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (11:46): I don't understand why he is talking about Opera
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:46): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: k
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:46): everyone seems to call it -76
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:46): yeah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:46): dunno what chrome and safari actually implement
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (11:46): the problem is not the second or third browser doing something unprefixed, it's the first one

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:47): http://my.opera.com/core/blog/websockets -- "Opera supports version -00 of the protocol (aka -76). This is the same as Chrome 6, Safari 5.02 and Firefox 4 beta."
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:47): it'd be nice if there was a test suite online somewhere :-)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (11:47): i thought -00 and -76 were the same version
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:47): they are
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:47): the question is whether it's -00 or -00-updated
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:47): confusingly called "-latest"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:47): the version before ifette took over
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:48): we do the one with two types framing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:48): so -00 then
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:48): probably with some of the fixes from "-latest"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:48): man this is confusing
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:48): and we have a test suite released, but you need to set it up
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:48): i hope ifette gets a spec out there soon
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:48): with the rate hybi is going through things, I don't have high hopes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:48): i really just want us to do TLS-only at this point
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:49): with only wss:
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (11:49): why only wss?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:49): i don't see the point of ws: if it's not trivial to implement
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:49): and we've clearly gone way past "trivial to implement"
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (11:50): i thought there was a use case of intermediaries being able to inspect the payload
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:50): It isn't at all clear to me that it is just as easy for a simple application using a prewritten server to use wss as ws
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:51): I would presume wss requires the author to care about certificates and complex stuff like that
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:51): Way too high a barrier to entry
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:52): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: i don't know of a real use case for that

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:53): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: well we can add something to the API to disable cert checking if people think that that's useful. But I don't think a single 's' difference is enough of a red flag if we're going down that route, really.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:55): Well it is exactly like http, which might not be ideal but has the advantage that people understand it
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:56): I don't think the right response to "we can't make it trivial" is "let's add loads of difficulty"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:57): It is still trivial as long as someone else writes the code to do the handshake and decode the frames
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (12:03): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: yeah, s/not/no was the difference. I didn't have a chance to add more info.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:06): np thanks
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:12): i love that http://dev.w3.org/html5/html-xhtml-author-guide/html-xhtml-authoring-guide.html doesn't even remotely try to be polyglot
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:13): To be clear, I assume that no one advocating prefixing the websockets API expects it to have any effect other than as a "this is experimental" signal?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:15): first two videos from #fronteers10: http://vimeo.com/channels/140223 first is from adactio on the Design of HTML5
